judge: Stabler, Brease, Messrs, Carter, Bonham, Cothran

opinions.snippet:
June 14, 1934. The opinion of the Court was delivered by
This is an action for damages based upon fraud and deceit alleged to have been practiced upon plaintiff by the defendant company through its agent Catlin.
The plaintiff alleged, inter alia, that in March, 1930, she learned that her brother, Ben O. Hood, had with the defendant company a health and accident policy of insurance, in which she was designated as beneficiary, and that he was thinking of discontinuing it; that p

posture: Before SEASE, J., York, August, 1931. Reversed and case remanded with instructions.Action by Carrie Hood against the Life  Casualty Insurance Company of Tennessee and another. From a judgment in favor of the plaintiff, the defendants appeal.

opinions.snippet:
The plaintiff recovered a verdict and judgment of $25,000 for injuries received in a collision with the defendant's truck, and the defendant appeals.
The plaintiff's father and mother were riding in the front seat of an automobile, the father driving. Plaintiff, a girl four years of age, was in the rear seat alone. They were traveling a much used paved highway from Tulsa to Dawson, Okla. At the scene of the accident outside of the city limits, the highway runs in a northeasterly direct

posture:

Personal injury action for damages by Norma June Perrin against Shell Petroleum Corporation and another. Judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appeal. Affirmed.

opinions.snippet:
Argued April 21, 1943.
Minor plaintiff, John E. Williams, Jr., nine years old, was injured as a result of a fall through a skylight constructed upon a roof of defendant's factory premises at the southeast corner of Otterman and Washington Streets, in Greensburg. The plant was built upon land bounded on the north by Otterman Street, on the west by Washington Street, on the east by a cement alley, on the south partly by lands of other owners from which it was divided by a fence, and on the sout

posture:
Appeals, Nos. 20 and 21, April T., 1943, from judgment
of C.P. Westmoreland Co., Aug. T., 1939, No. 653, in case of John E. Williams, Jr., by his father and next friend, John Williams and John E. Williams and Celestine Williams, in their own right, v. Overly Manufacturing Company. Judgments reversed.

Trespass for personal injuries. Before KEENAN, P.J.

Verdicts, for minor plaintiff in sum of $1,750 and for parent plaintiffs in sum of $672 and judgments thereon. Defendant appealed.

opinions.snippet:
Opinion for the court filed by Circuit Judge J. SKELLY WRIGHT.
J. SKELLY WRIGHT, Circuit Judge.

attorney: William McLean Pitts, T. G. Gayle, J. E. Wilkinson, Jr., Selma, Ala., for appellant., J. S. Mead, Emmett R. Cox, Birmingham, Ala., John Randolph Smith, Selma, Ala. (Mead & Norman, Birmingham, Ala., of counsel), for appellees.
caseName: Dallas County v. Commercial Union Assurance Company, Ltd.
caseNameFull: DALLAS COUNTY, Appellant, v. COMMERCIAL UNION ASSURANCE COMPANY, Ltd., Et Al., Appellees
court: Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit

opinions.snippet:
WISDOM, Circuit Judge.
 

  This appeal presents a single question — the admissibility in evidence of a newspaper to show that the Dallas County Courthouse in Selma, Alabama, was damaged by fire in 1901. We hold that the newspaper was admissible, and affirm the judgment below.
 

  On a bright, sunny morning, July 7, 195

attorney: Arthur Berman, with him Samuel Handler and Gompton, Handler & Berman, for appellants., John Mel. Smith, with him James H. Stewart, Jr., Wilhelm E. Shissler and Nauman, Smith, Shissler <& Hall, for appellee.
caseNameFull: Scibelli v. Pennsylvania Railroad Company
judge: Bell, Chidsey, Jones, Musmanno, Stearne, Stern

opinions.snippet:
Dissenting Opinion bt
Me. Justice Musmanno :
The Majority Opinion treats this case as if the plaintiff Frank A. Scibelli were an adult. In point of fact, of course, he was at the time of the accident involved only seven years of age.
